ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great foundation in Caribbean theory & literature

I learned a lot about diasporic ethnic studies and current discourse happening in the area. Not much writing feedback, or presenting, but I definitely walked away with a new framework for thinking about racial/ethnic relations in life and their manifestations in literature
I gained knowledge about the Caribbean diaspora and how race, gender, and sexuality have constructed into diasporic identity.

I discovered a whole new world of literature through this course. This being my first literature class at Yale, the selected novels and essays were an interesting and fun set to read. The projects allowed me to interact with the course in an interdisciplinary way,

I learned so much about the Caribbean through reading fiction and nonfiction texts. I also became a better public speaker. I learned how to synthesize texts to understand what is there and what was left out.
I gained an insightful understanding of the literary works of the Caribbean Diaspora.
This course was extremely insightful and provided me with reading and frameworks useful for all of my other classes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: this course could use a TA, or something to give it structurally more direction. The course's reading list was broad and well thought out. Habchi was incredibly responsive and supportive when prompted but there wasn't too much built-in straightforwardness to approaching assignments to this class
Strengths were that the books and material were very engaging. I also liked how I was able to hear from my peers and how they interpreted the material with weekly presentations.
The only weakness is speed. I wish we spent 2 weeks on each text instead.

The teaching was great, the works we read were extremely interested, and the engagement was high. The topics were extremely though-provoking, but sometimes it felt like way too much in one class that I came out more confused than understanding.
loved the readings, the time of the class was a little late.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes absolutely. Great Hu and low-stress english course. Habchi is great and wants you to succeed and engage with the material
I would recommend this course because the material was extremely engaging and Professor Hibachi is amazing.
Yes, the readings were very interesting and the Professor is knowledgable and encourages students participation.
I would. I love Professor Habchi and the class environment that she fostered. All of the texts were amazing and truly transformative.
Yes, if you are interested in literature of the Caribbean Diaspora and the intersecting issues that influence the Caribbean today, this is a great course.
